title: "How can eye contact and body language improve your communication skills in important situations?"
first_phrase: In the last part of this text, the author provides tips on how to make a strong impression in personal interactions. They advise on the importance of making eye contact and holding it steadily during crucial moments, such as when concluding a conversation or meeting someone for the first time. The author suggests limiting conversation topics to those of interest to the other person and handling disagreement with courtesy and persuasive arguments. A triumphant attitude should be avoided even if one has succeeded in persuading the other person. These tips can empower individuals to turn conversations to their advantage and leave a lasting impression.
content: When walking into someoneâ€™s presence: If you walk inside an office so as to approach a man sitting by his desk, look at him well in his face as soon as he raises his eyes in order to welcome you. He must cross your look at the time when the latter is already fixed upon his person. By doing as instructed, you shall produce a very powerful effect of surprise. Remember also that, once the conversation with him has begun, one of the golden rules is to limit your selves to talk about those issues which might be of interest to him. If you happen to be contradicted regarding what you are saying, avoid getting scandalized, especially if the individual who is refuting what you are saying is in the right. In the event that you believe yourselves to be in the right, it will be necessary to courteously adduce some arguments which might cause them to think over your points. An even more pressing requirement is never to adopt a triumphant attitude when you have succeeded in persuading them.
last_phrase: In summary, when entering someone's presence, it is important to make a powerful and surprising first impression by maintaining eye contact and limiting the conversation to the other person's interests. If disagreed with, remain calm and courteously offer persuasive arguments without being triumphant. Additionally, establish a positive inner attitude before arriving to engage in an "ocular greeting" for an even stronger impact. Remember, the way you enter a room can set the tone for the entire interaction.
